subject: RE: [junit] assertTrue
msgSnippet: It was changed to assertTrue for future compatibility with JDK 1.4 where assert is going to be a java keyword. Elio Maldonado
messageBody:
It was changed to assertTrue for future compatibility with JDK 1.4 where
assert is going to be a java keyword.

Elio Maldonado

> -----Original Message-----
> From: rainsber@... [SMTP:rainsber@...]
> Sent: Friday, July 06, 2001 9:52 AM
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: Re: [junit] assertTrue
>
> I must concur. I wonder, why the change to "assertTrue" from "assert"? The
> old model seemed more logical: "assert" is the atomic action and common
> assertions are built in terms of "assert", so it makes sense that "assert"
> be the base name and "assertX" be a shorthand for "assert(X)".
>
> J. B. Rainsberger <rainsber@...>
> Commerce Suite Accelerator: Rule Services, IBM Toronto Lab
> 8200 Warden Av, Office A3-735 [A3/FNB/8200/MKM]
> Markham ON L6G 1C7
> 905 413-2501 (969-2501)
>
>
> "Coulman, Randy" <RCoulman@...> on 07/06/2001 12:31:31
>
> Please respond to junit@yahoogroups.com
>
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> cc:
> Subject: [junit] assertTrue
>
>
>
>
> I just moved up to JUnit 3.7, and I'm beginning to convert existing code
> to use assertTrue instead of assert.
>
> Does anyone else find it odd to write something like:
>
> assertTrue(!someCondition);
>
> I had no problem with assert(!someCondition), but it reads funny with
> assertTrue().
>
> Would it make sense to add a corresponding assertFalse(someCondition) to
> JUnit? I know it is redundant in a sense, but I think it would
> communicate better.
>
> Randy
> --
> Randy Coulman
> Senior Software Engineer
> Key Technology, Inc.
> RCoulman@...
